facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 95 of 1952 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 95 of 1952.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and decree dated 27th February 1950 of High Court of Judicature at Madras by Rao and Ayyar JJ in Appeal No. 635 of 1946.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated the 27th February, 1950, of the High Court of Judicature at Madras  Rao and Ayyar JJ.  in Appeal No. 635 of 1946

facts.text: High Court appeal arose from judgment and decree dated 13th August 1946 of Subordinate Judge of Tinnevelly in Original Suit No. 50 of 1945.

anchor.surface_text: arising, out of judgment and decree dated the 13th August, 1946, of the Court of the Subordinate Judge of Tinnevelly in Original Suit No. 50 of 1945.

facts.text: Lakshminarayana Iyer owned considerable properties in Tirunelveli district.

anchor.surface_text: One Lakshminarayana Iyer, a Hindu Brahmin, who owned companysiderable properties in the Tirunelveli district,

facts.text: Lakshminarayana Iyer died on 13th December 1924 leaving widow Ranganayaki and married daughter Ramalakshmi.

anchor.surface_text: died on 13th December, 1924, leaving him surviving a widow Ranganayaki, and a married daughter Ramalakshmi.

facts.text: Ramalakshmi married the plaintiff and had a number of children from him all alive in December 1924.

anchor.surface_text: Ramalakshmi had married the plaintiff and had a number of children from him. They were all alive in December, 1924,

facts.text: Lakshminarayana executed a will on 16th November 1924 construction of which is in controversy.

anchor.surface_text: when Lakshminarayana died, Before his death he executed a will on 16th November, 1924, the companystruction

facts.text: By will wife Ranganayaki to enjoy entire properties till her lifetime then daughter Ramalakshmi and her heirs to enjoy with absolute rights and powers of alienation.

anchor.surface_text: By this will he gave the following directions -- After my lifetime, you, the aforesaid Ranganayaki Amminal, my wife, shall till your lifetime, enjoy the aforesaid entire properties, the outstandings due to me, the debts payable by me, and the chit amounts payable by me. After your lifetime Ramalakshmi Ammal, our daughter and wife of Rama Ayyar Avergal of Melagaram village, and her heirs shall enjoy them with absolute rights and powers of alienation such as gift, exchange, and sale from son to grandson and so on for generations.

facts.text: Will directed wife Ranganayaki to pay maintenance to Chinnanmal alias Lakshmi Ammal wife of late son Hariharamayyan and obtain release deed.

anchor.surface_text: As regards the payment of maintenance to be made to Chinnanmal alias Lakshmi Ammal, wife of my late son Hariharamayyan, my wife Ranganayaki Ammal shall pay the same as she pleases, and obtain a release deed.

facts.text: Ranganayaki entered into possession of properties on death of husband.

anchor.surface_text: Ranganayaki entered into possession of the properties on the death of her husband.

facts.text: On 21st February 1928 Ranganayaki settled maintenance claim of Lakshmi Ammal paid Rs. 3350 cash executed agreement for Rs. 240 per annum and obtained release deed.

anchor.surface_text: On 21st February, 1928, she settled the maintenance claim of Lakshmi Ammal and obtained a deed of release from her by paying her a sum of Rs. 3,350 in cash and by executing in her favour an agreement stipulating to pay her a sum of Rs. 240 per annum.

facts.text: Ramalakshmi died on 25th April 1938 during lifetime of widow none of her children survived her.

anchor.surface_text: Ramalakshmi died on 25th April, 1938 during the lifetime of the widow. None of her children survived her.

facts.text: On 24th July 1945 widow sold one item of property to 2nd defendant for Rs. 500 describing herself as absolute owner.

anchor.surface_text: On the 24th July, 1945, the widow describing herself as an absolute owner of the properties of her husband sold one of the items of the property to the 2nd defendant for Rs. 500.

facts.text: Suit instituted on 18th September 1945 by plaintiff husband and sole heir of Ramalakshmi for declaration that sale not binding beyond widow lifetime and restrain alienation.

anchor.surface_text: On the 18th September, 1945, the suit out of which this appeal arises was instituted by the plaintiff, the husband and the sole heir of Ramalakshmi, for a declaration that the said sale would number be binding on him beyond the lifetime of the widow. A prayer was made that the widow be restrained from alienating the other properties in her possession.

facts.text: On 19th September 1945 ad interim injunction issued by High Court restraining widow from alienating properties.

anchor.surface_text: On the 19th September, 1945, an ad interim injunction was issued by the High Court restraining the widow from alienating the properties in her possession and forming part of her husbands estate,

facts.text: On 27th September 1945 despite injunction widow executed two deeds of settlement in favour of other defendants.

anchor.surface_text: In spite of this injunction, on the 27th September, 1945, she executed two deeds of settlement in favour of the other defendants companyprising a number of properties.

facts.text: Plaintiff amended plaint to include prayer for declaration of invalidity of the two settlements.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiff was allowed to amend his plaint and include therein a prayer for a declaration in respect of the invalidity of these alienations as well.

facts.text: Plaintiff averred Ramalakshmi obtained vested interest in properties under will.

anchor.surface_text: It was averred in the plaint that Ramalakshmi obtained a vested interest in the suit -properties under the will of her father

facts.text: Defendants pleaded plaintiff had no title to sue widow entitled to absolute estate or at least widows estate daughters estate contingent she predeceased no interest to plaintiff.

anchor.surface_text: The defendants pleaded that the plaintiff had numbertitle to maintain the suit, that the widow was entitled under the will to an absolute estate or at least to an estate analogous to and number less than a widows estate, that the estate given to Ramalakshmi under the will was but a companytingent one and she having predeceased the widow, numberinterest in the suit properties devolved on the plaintiff.

facts.text: Subordinate Judge held widow took limited life interest not absolute or Hindu widows estate daughter got vested interest plaintiff succeeded granted declaratory decree alienations not enure beyond lifetime validity undetermined.

anchor.surface_text: The subordinate judge held that the widow took under the will a limited life, interest, and number an absolute estate or even a widows estate under Hindu law, and that the daughter got thereunder a vested interest in the properties to which the plaintiff succeeded on her death. In view of this finding he granted the plaintiff a declaratory decree to the effect that the first defendant had only an estate for life in the suit properties and that the alienations made by her would number enure beyond her lifetime. The question as to the validity of the alienations was left undetermined.

facts.text: Unsuccessful defendants appealed to High Court Madras.

anchor.surface_text: The unsuccessful defendants preferred an appeal against this decree to the High Court of Judicature at Madras.

facts.text: Widow died on 14th February 1948 during pendency of appeal.

anchor.surface_text: During the pendency of the appeal the widow died on 14th February, 1948.

facts.text: High Court affirmed trial judge decision on construction of will.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court by its judgment under appeal affirmed the decision of the trial judge and maintained his view on the companystruction of the will.

facts.text: Leave to appeal to Supreme Court granted appeal admitted on 27th November 1951.

anchor.surface_text: Leave to appeal to the Supreme Court was granted and the appeal was admitted on the 27th November, 1951.

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered on 14 April 1953 by MAHAJAN J.

anchor.surface_text: 1953. April 14. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by MAHAJAN J.--

anchor.surface_text: Leave to appeal to the Supreme Court was granted and the appeal was admitted on the 27th November, 1951.

issues.text: The main issue in the suit was whether the widow took under the will an absolute estate or an estate like the Hindu widows estate and whether the daughters interest therein was in the nature of a contingent remainder, or whether she got in the properties a vested interest.

anchor.surface_text: The main issue in the suit was whether- the widow took under the will an absolute estate or an estate like the Hindu widows estate and whether the daughters interest therein was in the nature of a contingent remainder, or whether she got in the properties a vested interest.

issues.text: The substantial question to decide in the appeal is whether the estate granted by the testator to his widow was a full womans estate under Hindu law or merely a limited life estate in the English sense of that expression.

anchor.surface_text: The substantial question to decide in the appeal is whether the estate granted by the testator to his widow was a fall womans estate under Hindu law or merely a limited life estate in the English sense of that expression.

issues.text: the decision of the appeal thus turns upon the question whether the testators intention was to give to his widow an ordinary life estate or an estate analogous to that of a Hindu widow.
